Science has removed the distance of place. It has saved time. We also have wonderful means of travel. Cars and buses are very common. Electric trains carry us across the land with great speed. Jet planes go like a flash across the sky. Thus speedy travel is possible only on account of the wonders of science. With the help of science, we have even reached the moon. Soon we are going to visit other planets.
Science has done great magic in the field of communication. Telephone, Fax, wireless, mobile phone, internet, etc. – all great wonders of science, have conquered time, space, and distance and brought the world closer to us.
The invention of computers is the greatest wonder of modern science. In fact, the computer is reigning all over the previous inventions that mankind has ever made possible. Using internet technology with computers has brought another revolution for man. It has made the world fastest which is beyond imagination. It has turned the world a global village.

questions.uddipok: Deforestation has a great impact on Bangladesh. Because of deforestation our country is gradually turning into a desert. Now, write a short composition on "Deforestation and its Adverse Consequences." Use 200-250 words.

sub_questions.explanation:
The world is losing most of its natural resources as and when you read this. There are many factors which are making this happen, however, one major concern is that of deforestation. Human activities are resulting in deforestation at a very rapid rate. Moreover, the effects of this activity are very dangerous. We do not realize the damage we are causing to living beings as well as the vegetation by cutting down trees. It will be clearer if we understand the impact of deforestation and make attempts to prevent it.

Impact of Deforestation
When we cut down even a single tree, the impact it has is huge. Now imagine if we clear out whole forests only altogether, how damaging would that be. We cut down forests to meet the needs of humans. In order to fulfill the agricultural, commercial, industrial, residential and other needs we remove forests. Most of the earth was covered with forests until a hundred years ago, however, now we don’t have much of them left.
Deforestation causes disruption in the ecological balance. Moreover, it also interferes with the lives of wildlife and human beings as well. Firstly, when there won’t be many forests left, the water cycle of the earth will get disturbed. There won’t be enough trees left to absorb the water. Moreover, it will cause floods and droughts too. Similarly, soil erosion will be another effect of deforestation.
Other than that, the climate will experience massive change. Global warming is also happening partly due to deforestation only. The oxygen level in the atmosphere will drop down by a great number and thus naturally carbon dioxide levels will increase. Most importantly, the wildlife is losing their habitats due to deforestation. Forests are their only home and with no place left to go, they either lose their lives or wreak havoc in the cities.
Therefore, we must all come together to stop this from happening and saving our earth as well as our lives. Humans must not be so selfish so as to make other animals homeless to shelter themselves. We must not damage our vegetation to create a beautiful garden for ourselves.
How to Prevent Deforestation?
We can do a lot of things that will contribute to preventing deforestation. To begin with, do not waste paper. The more demand there will be the more supply will happen. This way, trees will keep getting cut to meet these needs.
Similarly, the government must put a ban on deforestation so the big firms can find other alternatives instead of clearing forests for commercial and industrial needs. The laws must be made stringent enough and also implemented properly to prevent it.
Moreover, there must be measures taken to control the increasing population. As there are more mouths to feed and fewer resources, our nature and forests are getting burdened. There is not adequate supply to meet the ever-increasing demands of the population. Thus, the lesser the demand, the better the conditions of the forests as well.

questions.uddipok: Internet is influencing our young generation both positively and negatively. Write a composition on the 'Uses and Abuses of Internet'. Write at least 200 words but don't exceed 250 words.

sub_questions.explanation:
The number of internet users around the world is increasing drastically with every passing day and so is the number of internet addicts. The world of internet is extremely alluring. Video games, chat rooms, social media platforms, entertainment videos, engrossing web series and interesting blogs can keep a person hooked for hours. Many people begin to use internet as a means to overcome loneliness and boredom and get addicted to it within no time.

Introduction of Smart Phones Responsible for Growing Internet Addiction
Around a decade back when internet could only be accessed on desktop and laptop, the internet usage was limited. Many people were still addicted to it. They spent several hours in front of their systems surfing internet. Many people frequently visited cyber cafes to access internet. However, the situation wasn’t as bad as it is today.
The introduction of smart phones has given internet access to large number of people. Smart phones are said to be one of the major causes of internet addiction in today’s times. People are seen glued to internet even as they travel or attend a social event. Some of them are obsessed with chatting apps, others are addicted to gaming while yet others are busy updating and checking their social media accounts.
The introduction of various kinds of web series has increased internet addiction. It is an easy source of entertainment and extremely addictive. Binge watching web series is quite common among people around the world. Internet addicts forget to eat, complete important tasks, and ignore their loved ones. All they want is a high speed internet connection and a device to access it. This is straining their personal relationships and hampering their work.
Conclusion
Internet addiction is a serious disorder that blurs a person’s ability to think rationally. Even though internet addicts know the harmful consequences of this addiction and begin to feel the heat they do not make much effort to overcome it. This often leads to serious problems such as depression, anxiety and other mental health disorders.

questions.uddipok: Do you agree with the view that smartphones have done us more harm than good? Compare and contrast the benefits and the drawbacks of these devices.

sub_questions.explanation:
The debate over whether smartphones have done more harm than good is a highly relevant and contentious issue in today's digital age. Smartphones have undoubtedly brought about significant changes in how we communicate, work, and interact with the world. However, while they offer numerous benefits, there are also serious drawbacks associated with their widespread use. Below, I will compare and contrast both the positive and negative impacts of smartphones to assess whether they have done us more harm than good.
Benefits of Smartphones
1. Improved Communication: One of the most significant advantages of smartphones is the way they have revolutionized communication. They allow us to stay connected with people from anywhere in the world, whether through calls, text messages, social media, or video conferencing. This ease of communication has bridged geographical gaps and helped maintain relationships, both personally and professionally.
2. Access to Information: Smartphones have put vast amounts of information at our fingertips. With internet access, we can look up anything from news and research to how-to guides and educational content. This instant access to knowledge has empowered people to learn new skills, make informed decisions, and stay updated on global events.
3. Convenience and Efficiency: Smartphones have made many tasks more convenient and efficient. With apps for banking, shopping, navigation, and work, they enable us to accomplish daily tasks quickly and with ease. For example, mobile banking allows people to transfer money, pay bills, or check their accounts without having to visit a bank.
4. Entertainment and Socialization: Smartphones provide a wide variety of entertainment options, including movies, music, games, and social media platforms. They allow people to stay entertained during commutes or in moments of downtime, and they have created new avenues for social interaction, especially through social networks and messaging apps.
5. Work Flexibility: With smartphones, many people can work remotely, check emails, manage projects, and attend meetings without being tied to an office. This has increased workplace flexibility, which is especially valuable for people with busy schedules or those who live in remote areas.
Drawbacks of Smartphones
1. Health Issues: Prolonged smartphone use has been linked to various health problems. Excessive screen time can lead to eye strain, headaches, and disrupted sleep patterns due to blue light exposure. Additionally, the sedentary lifestyle promoted by constant smartphone usage contributes to physical health issues such as obesity, poor posture, and back problems.
2. Addiction and Dependency: Smartphones can be addictive. Many people find it hard to go a few hours without checking their phones, leading to reduced productivity and social isolation. The constant notifications and the desire for instant gratification through social media can foster an unhealthy dependency, impacting mental health by causing anxiety, stress, and depression.
3. Privacy Concerns: With smartphones constantly connected to the internet, they are vulnerable to cyberattacks, hacking, and data breaches. Personal information, such as location data, contacts, and browsing history, can be exploited by malicious entities. Privacy concerns are particularly pronounced with the increasing use of smartphones for online transactions, banking, and shopping.
4. Distraction and Reduced Attention Span: Smartphones are a significant source of distraction, especially in environments that require focus, such as the workplace or school. Constant notifications and the lure of social media apps can make it difficult to concentrate on important tasks, leading to reduced productivity. Studies have shown that smartphone use is also shortening attention spans, as people tend to multitask and switch between activities rapidly.
5. Social Isolation: While smartphones enable communication, they can also contribute to social isolation. People may opt for texting or messaging instead of face-to-face interactions, leading to a reduction in meaningful, personal connections. This "virtual connection" often lacks the depth and quality of in-person relationships, contributing to feelings of loneliness and alienation.
Conclusion
While smartphones offer numerous benefits that enhance our lives, from improving communication and access to information to making our daily tasks more convenient, they also come with significant drawbacks. The negative impacts—such as health problems, addiction, privacy concerns, and social isolation—highlight that the overuse of smartphones can be harmful.
In my opinion, whether smartphones have done us more harm than good depends on how they are used. If used mindfully, with proper boundaries and awareness of their potential downsides, smartphones can be powerful tools for personal and professional growth. However, if used excessively or irresponsibly, they can lead to harmful consequences. Ultimately, it is essential to strike a balance and use smartphones in a way that maximizes their benefits while minimizing their drawbacks.

questions.uddipok: Write a composition on adulteration of foodstuff with clear references to the causes and consequences.

sub_questions.explanation:
Adulteration of Foodstuff: Causes and Consequences
Adulteration of foodstuff refers to the practice of intentionally adding harmful, low-quality, or synthetic substances to food items in order to increase profits. It is a serious issue that affects public health and undermines consumer trust. Adulterated food is often cheaper to produce but can pose significant health risks to those who consume it unknowingly.
Causes of Food Adulteration
One of the primary causes of food adulteration is the economic motive behind it. Sellers and manufacturers may use adulterants to increase the quantity or shelf life of food products, thereby reducing costs. For example, low-quality or artificial substances are often added to increase the weight of spices, grains, or beverages. This is especially common in the case of products like milk, tea, sugar, and edible oils.
The lack of stringent regulations and enforcement also contributes to the prevalence of food adulteration. In many countries, food safety laws are not strictly implemented, allowing unscrupulous traders to exploit gaps in the system. In some cases, poor awareness among consumers about food safety and quality standards makes it easier for adulterated food to enter the market without detection.
Another significant cause is the greed of certain manufacturers and traders. In their quest for higher profits, they compromise on quality and safety. For instance, chemicals, artificial colorants, and preservatives are added to food items like fruits, vegetables, and sweets to make them look fresh and appealing, despite the potential health risks they pose.
Consequences of Food Adulteration
The consequences of food adulteration are severe and can have both short-term and long-term effects on health. Immediate reactions to consuming adulterated food can include food poisoning, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea, which can be particularly dangerous for children and the elderly.
Long-term consumption of adulterated food can lead to chronic health problems, such as liver and kidney damage, cancer, and reproductive issues. For instance, the addition of harmful chemicals like formalin in fish or milk can lead to severe health complications over time. The accumulation of toxic substances in the body can weaken the immune system, making individuals more susceptible to diseases.
In addition to health risks, food adulteration also leads to economic losses for consumers. People pay for food products that are often less nutritious or potentially harmful. This can cause financial strain, especially in lower-income communities where access to safe food is already limited.
Moreover, food adulteration damages the reputation of businesses and industries that rely on consumer trust. Once a brand is associated with adulterated food, it can lose its customers and face legal consequences, leading to long-term financial losses.
Conclusion
In conclusion, food adulteration is a harmful practice with far-reaching consequences. The causes are multifaceted, including economic motives, lack of regulation, and consumer ignorance. The effects on health and the economy are undeniable, making it imperative for governments to enforce strict food safety regulations and for consumers to remain vigilant. Only through collective efforts can we ensure that the food we consume is safe, nutritious, and free from harmful adulterants.

questions.uddipok: Write a composition on "The Necessity of Compulsory ICT Education in Bangladesh".

sub_questions.explanation:
ICT Stands for "Information and Communication Technologies." It refers to technologies that provide access to information through telecommunications. It is defined as a diverse set of technological tools and resources used to communicate, and to create, disseminate, store, and manage information. At present it has created a "global village," in which people can communicate with others across the world as if they were living next door. For this reason, ICT is often studied in the context of how modern communication technologies affect society.
In the 21st century, Information Communication Technology (ICT) is one of the latest techniques around the world including Bangladesh to use in the field of education. In Bangladesh information and communications technology has been introduced as a compulsory subject at the junior secondary, secondary and higher secondary level. In line with the education policy 2010, the government introduced ICT for Class VI students in 2012, for Class VII in 2013, for Class Vill in 2014 and for Class IX in 2015. For the students of Class XI and XII, ICT subject was introduced in 2013.
Students would now be studying the ICT as a compulsory subject in addition to Bangla and English. The subject gives the students primary ideas about computer and its related devices, internet, mobile and their usages, which builds a foundation for further ICT studies. In Bangladesh, there is no alternative to compulsory ICT education. It can improve the quality of our life because it can be used as a learning and education media, the mass communication media in promoting and campaigning practical and important issues, such as the health and social area. It provides wider knowledge and can help in gaining and accessing information.
Moreover, we live in the digital age. The age requires a technologically competent work force. If our education systems fail to produce a technically literate population, it will hinder our ability to compete in the global economy. 21st century is completely technology driven since the people around the world do not think their life without technology. Those who have the technology they are developed and control the whole world so far. That is why, compulsory ICT education has no alternative. We hope, it will pave the way to producing the skilled, efficient and trained manpower. No doubt, it will be helpful for the students to cope with the challenges of the 21st century.

questions.uddipok: Write a short composition on 'Your Favourite Hobby '. Write at least 200 words but don't exceed 250 words

sub_questions.explanation:
My Favourite Hobby
Hobby is a kind of pleasant thing. Hobby means one's favourite occupation, but not one's main business. A man does not depend on it for his living. Hobby also means to do something willfully. It is an interesting work. It gives joy and pleasure on mind. It may not give us money but it gives us joy and pleasure. To spend leisure time every man chooses a hobby according to their taste. A man cannot enjoy his free time without hobby. So it is necessary to enjoy life.
There are many kinds of hobbies. Men are different in taste. Some of the common hobbies are gardening, fishing, stamp collecting, autograph collecting, reading books, keeping pets, kite flying, drawing picture, painting etc.
I am a student. So I have a hobby. My hobby is gardening. My garden is in front of my reading room. I have planted different kinds of flowers in my garden. They are the rose, the hasnahena, the rajanigandha, the gandhoraj, the cosmos, the sakal-sandha, the beli, etc. I work in my garden with a spade during my leisure period. I make the soil loose, weed out the grass and plant new flower plants. Sometimes I water them. From time to time I put cow dung to make the land fertile. I take great care of the plants. There is a strong fence around my garden so that the naughty boys and animals can do no harm to my flower plants.
One may ask why I like gardening as my hobby. In answer, I will say that gardening is very useful for the health and mind. Gardening does me a lot of good. It is very helpful to me. It refreshes my body and mind. It keeps me always in a jolly mood. For this I can attend to my studies with fresh energy. Everyday I get great pleasures when I see blooming flowers in my garden. I am charmed at their beauty when they are tossed by gentle breeze. I also get pleasure when the sweet scent of flowers come into my room. Besides this, I grow some vegetables in my garden. This saves a lot of expenses of my family. For this reason, I like gardening.
A hobby like gardening gives pleasure and instruction. It makes a man active and strong. It prevents a man to pass his time in idleness. It increases one's knowledge too. Through this one comes to know about flower's and plant's lives. It is also a sort of physical exercise. It gives us an opportunity to make physical labour and build our health properly. Physical labour and fresh air of the garden is very helpful for physical and mental health.
For a cheerful life every man should have a hobby. But we should see that our main works do not suffer on account of it.

questions.uddipok: Write a short composition on " Impact of Climate Change in Bangladesh ".

sub_questions.explanation:
Impact of Climate Change in Bangladesh
Long-term variation in temperatures and weather patterns is known as climate change. The frequent
shift of climate in Bangladesh has been showing a number of devastating effects, such as, rising sea level, floods and intensifying cyclones, Firstly, Rising sea level is a growing threat to people all around Bangladesh. To illustrate, Two-thirds of the land of this country is less than fifteen feet above sea level. So, the increase of sea level might cause extinction of huge low land area, Respondingly, The dwellers of the area may have to migrate from their own land. Secondly, Climate change is making rainfall more erratic and often far more intense. In terms of Bangladesh, this reality has recently become quite evident, Because of irregular rain and melting the Himalayan glaciers, Bangladesh is now far more vulnerable to devastating floods, Lastly and more importantly, The Bay of Bangal narrows towards its northern shore where it meets the south of coast Bangladesh. This narrowing can both direct cyclones towards Bangladesh's coast and make them more intense. To conclude, to minimize climate change, some immediate steps could be taken such as planting more trees, reducing the use of CFC gases, using electric vehicles, recycling plastic materials, In a word, People should practice eco-friendly behaviors to protect the nature as well as themselves.

questions.uddipok:
Recently the female leadership of Bangladesh has been praised superbly in an international conference in India.
Now, write a short composition on “ Students and Social Service ” using 200-250 words.

sub_questions.explanation:
We, the students of Bangladesh, are the future of our country. As youth, we have energy and passion that can be used to improve society. Though our main duty is to study hard, we also have a responsibility to help others in need.
There are many problems in our communities that we can try to solve through social work. Many people in villages and slums are uneducated. During holidays, we students can go to these areas to teach basic reading and writing. We can start makeshift schools under trees to educate both children and adults. Knowledge is power, and education can uplift their lives.
Poverty is also widespread across Bangladesh. We can encourage self-sufficiency by teaching vocational skills like sewing, farming, and small business management. We can work with microfinance organizations to help villagers take small loans to start their own enterprises. Financial independence can alleviate their hardship.
Health awareness is lacking, especially among the poor. We can educate people about cleanliness, nutrition, vaccinations, and preventive care. Girls can be especially effective in teaching women about maternal health, childcare and women’s rights. We can also run free health camps for checkups and medicine distribution.
Some regions face problems like water scarcity. We can mobilize resources to build wells and set up water filters to provide clean drinking water. We can teach sustainable practices like rainwater harvesting that people can implement themselves. Ensuring water access can greatly improve quality of life.
When floods, cyclones and other disasters hit Bangladesh, students can jump into action as volunteers. We can collect food, clothes and medicine to distribute to affected families. We can also directly participate in response efforts by helping evacuate people, setting up shelters, and providing emergency medical aid.
As youth, we represent progress, compassion and social justice. Every small effort we make improves our communities. The young generation has energy and inspiration that is vital for national development. Through continued education and service, we can create solutions and uplift our nation. We, the students of today, will lead Bangladesh towards prosperity tomorrow.
